description: From Middle English stiren, sturien, from Old English styrian (“to be in motion, move, agitate, stir, disturb, trouble”), from Proto-Germanic *sturiz (“turmoil, noise, confusion”), related to Proto-West Germanic *staurijan (“to destroy, disturb”). Cognate with Old Norse styrr (“turmoil, noise, confusion”), German stören (“to disturb”), Dutch storen (“to disturb”).

entries.meaning: The act or result of stirring (moving around the particles of a liquid etc.)
examples: Can you give the soup a little stir?

entries.meaning: agitation; tumult; bustle; noise or various movements.
examples: Why all these words, this clamour, and this stir?

entries.meaning: Public disturbance or commotion; tumultuous disorder; seditious uproar.
examples: Being advertised of some stirs raised by his unnatural sons in England.

verbs.description: stir (third-person singular simple present stirs, present participle stirring, simple past and past participle stirred)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disturb the relative position of the particles of (a liquid or similar) by passing an object through it.
examples: She stirred the pudding with a spoon.
He stirred his coffee so the sugar wouldn't stay at the bottom.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disturb the content of (a container) by passing an object through it.
examples: Would you please stir this pot so that the chocolate doesn't burn?
Synonyms: arouse, instigate, prompt, excite; see also Thesaurus:incite

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring into debate; to agitate.
(transitive, dated) To change the place of in any manner; to move.
(intransitive) To begin to move, especially gently, from a still or unmoving position.
(intransitive) Of a feeling or emotion: to rise, begin to be felt.
(intransitive) To be in motion; to be active or bustling; to exert or busy oneself.
(intransitive) To rise from sleep or unconsciousness.
examples: Synonyms: arise, get up, rouse; see also Thesaurus:wake

description: From Romani stariben (“prison”), nominalisation of (a)star (“seize”), causative of ast (“remain”), probably from Sanskrit आतिष्ठति (ātiṣṭhati, “stand or remain by”), from तिष्ठति (tiṣṭhati, “stand”).

examples: He's going to be spending maybe ten years in stir.
